columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to assess the price dilution.

Let us first identify the given amounts in the problem: 


| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Shares outstanding| 165,000|
|Share value |$77.00| 
|Market value of equity  |$12,705,000.00|
|New issuance| 30,000 shares|
|New issuance prices:||
|Price|$77.00|
|Price|$73.00|
|Price|$65.00|

The ex-rights price is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Ex-rights price}&=\dfrac{\text{(RN $\times$ S) + SP}}{\text{1 + RN }}\\
\end{aligned}$$ 

Where: 

RN = Rights needed 

S = Share price 

SP = Subscription price

First, let us determine the number of rights need to buy a share of stock. This is computed as follows: 



$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of rights }&=\dfrac{\text{Shares outstanding}}{\text{New shares}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{165,000}}{\text{30,000}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{5.5}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The number of rights required to buy stocks is 5.5 rights.**
